title.narrative: We are able! South Sudan

description.narrative: By 2025, through engagement with public authorities (formal and informal powerholders), men, women and youth with disabilities and other excluded groups, through resilient and capable local CSOs/DPOs in this fragile and conflict-affected country, are successfully influencing laws, policies, practices and norms for improved food security for all.

The We are able! program targets people (including women, men, and youth) with a disability, while, as spin-off, the program will also create opportunities for other excluded groups,3 such as vulnerable women, persons affected by leprosy, youth in general, excluded ethnic groups, internally displaced persons (IDPs) and refugees, as much as possible or necessary in the specific context. Intersectional traits often make people particularly vulnerable. Refugees with disabilities or disabled women and men of particular ethnic backgrounds often face the most severe forms of food insecurity. We are able! identifies and targets groups and individuals with particular vulnerabilities while creating synergies that allow others to benefit as well.

The activities in South Sudan are part of the We are able! program in DR Congo, Burundi, Ethiopia, South Sudan, Sudan and Uganda. Food security in these countries is low. People with disabilities (PWDs) are even more likely to live in food insecure households. We are able! wants to see PWDs improving their right to food and food security by creating an enabling environment for right-to-food action at grassroots level. While PWDs are the core target group of the We are able! program, we create benefits for other excluded groups like vulnerable women, youth in general, marginalised ethnic groups and internally displaced persons (IDPs), as applicable per context.

title.narrative: SCS3 # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage Methodological notes
# of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage at national and international level

comment.narrative: 1) Community Empowerment for Progress Organisation: CEPO developed an advocacy paper on the importance of having a National Technical Committee on Inclusion of persons with disabilities at presidency level in the country. The one page advocacy document was targeted at the Vice President on Gender and Youth Cluster. As a result the Committee was established and now waiting for the nomination of its members from Government, UN Agencies, INGOs and Civil Society. A senior policy advisor on matters concerning persons with disabilities has already been appointed in the office of the vice president. This position helps to ensure inclusivity of persons with disabilities in all sectors of the government. 2) Community Empowerment for Progress Organisation: Sign language translation had been adopted and is being used on the national TV (SSBC - South Sudan Broadcasting Cooperation). The organisation lobbied for a sign language instructor through the ministry of telecommunication, broadcasting and postal service South Sudan.

title.narrative: # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage at sub-national level

comment.narrative: 1) Community Empowerment for Progress Organisation: National Disabilities Voices Roundtables are organized regularly. This process involved various stakeholders like; NGOs, CSOs, Government officials and Faith based groups. 2) Jonglei Disability Organisation (JDO): Changed decision making processes and policy discussions related to inclusion of persons with disabilities in WFPs biometric registration in Bor. The organisation advocated for the inclusion of persons with disabilities in the WFPs biometric registration process. In most cases persons with disabilities are usually side-lined when it comes to beneficiary registration. At times persons with disabilities cannot reach the registration sites which makes them miss out on aid delivery. JDO informed the Relief Rehabilitation Commission (RRC) and the UN on ways they could improve on the inclusivity of persons with disabilities as beneficiary of aid delivery in the community.

SCS4 # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency
# of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency at sub-national level

comment.narrative: 1) Jonglei Disability Organisation (JDO): The organisation advocated for the wellbeing of PWD by organizing awareness sessions with the local authorities, religious leaders, youth and women leaders. The main aim was to have one voice advocating towards the wellbeing PWDs and PWVs through promoting inclusiveness and the rights of persons with disabilities.
